text:
- So two guys from Boston
figured out how you

can hang on to your
favorite t-shirts
just a little while longer.

I mean, sometimes they're
too old, they're too small,
but they have so many memories.

Here's today's small
business success.

ROSS LOHR: We make it
really easy and affordable

to turn all your memorable
t-shirts into t-shirt quilts.

NATHAN ROTHSTEIN: My
name is Nathan Rothstein.

ROSS LOHR: My name
is Ross Lohr, and I'm
a co-founder of Project Repat.

NATHAN ROTHSTEIN: We were both
at business school together.

ROSS LOHR: I ended up working
with a fashion designer,

trying out a bunch of different
samples of things made out

of t-shirts, but every time
we tried to sell those,

people would just say, I want
an affordable t-shirt quilt.

You can only hear
something so many times

before you realize, hey, maybe
this is the actual idea we
should be working on.

NATHAN ROTHSTEIN:
We really thought

about how to make a t-shirt that
is as affordable as possible

and as a efficient to make by
not making the quilt the way

your aunt or mother or
grandmother would make it.
ROSS LOHR: Beauty.

NATHAN ROTHSTEIN:
We're the only ones
who make 1,500 of these a week.

We know that for every
t-shirt quilt that we sell,

we're recycling at
least 15 t-shirts

and we're creating two
hours of work in the US.

ROSS LOHR: We set up a pretty
wide base of people who loved

our product, and from there
it was able to snowball
into 4 million in sales.

We are very much on a mission
to recycle as many t-shirts,

make a memorable product,
and put as many people
to work as possible.

NATHAN ROTHSTEIN: And
I think what we're

doing is helping
Americans recycle,

but in a way that they don't
have to even think about it.
- It's only about $75 a quilt.
